meta.title: Ruptura — Your Economic Reality
meta.description: See how you've been affected. Anonymous. No tracking.

lines.text: Every hour you work generates revenue, keeps systems running, helps people.
You know this. Your employer knows this.
But those who profit from your work have captured the rewards.
Wages haven't matched productivity in decades.
Rent outpaces income. Surveillance replaces raises.
We built these tools to show you exactly how much value you create.
Enter your numbers below and see the real cost of working for someone else's profit.

stats.text: — that's how much worker productivity has grown since 1979. Hourly pay grew just 24% in the same period.
U.S. employers steal $50 billion in wages from workers every year — more than all robberies, burglaries, and car thefts combined.
Employers set the wages for 80% of U.S. workers. You take it or leave it.
stats.source: Treasury Dept. Report on Labor Market Competition

stats.text: 47% of full-time workers cannot cover a $400 emergency. The problem is not your budgeting. It is your paycheck.

phase3a.reframe: They didn't ask your permission. Why are you asking for theirs?

blocks.question: Am I just being picky?
blocks.answer: You're not being picky. The data shows you've earned {{worth_gap_annual}} less per year than workers with your experience in your area. That's not a feeling — it's a number.

blocks.question: But what if my employer can't afford raises?
blocks.answer: National productivity has grown {{total_productivity_growth}} while wages grew just {{total_wage_growth}}. The money exists. The question is who gets it.

blocks.question: What if I get fired for asking?
blocks.answer: Federal law (NLRA Section 7) protects your right to discuss wages and working conditions with coworkers. Retaliation for this is illegal. You have more protection than you think.

blocks.question: Does this actually work?
blocks.answer: Workers who negotiate receive an average of 7.4% higher pay. Workers who negotiate collectively receive 10-25% more. The data is clear: asking works.

wins.text: Newly unionized workers see an average 18% wage increase in their first contract.
UPS Teamsters won a $7.50/hour raise for part-time workers in 2023 — the largest contract in their history.
Starbucks workers who unionized won guaranteed minimum hours, scheduling improvements, and tip sharing.
Amazon warehouse workers in Staten Island voted to form the first Amazon union in U.S. history in 2022.
